properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm weather continues. This warm airmass will persist over southern Quebec today. Daytime highs are expected to reach between 29 and 31 degrees Celsius with humidex values in the mid thirties. Cooler temperatures are forecast for the end of the week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain possible today. An area of rain moving northward from Ohio this morning will cross lake Erie and western sections of Lake Ontario through the middle of the day. There is the potential for rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 millimetres to fall across some areas by this evening. This rain is associated with the remnants of tropical depression Bertha and is weakening as it moves northward. There is still uncertainty about which area will receive the highest amount of rain however rainfall warnings may be issued this morning. This statement will be updated through today. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-29T00:49:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T08:50:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2799127630.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First heat event of the season continues through today. Daytime temperatures near thirty are expected again today with humidex values in the mid thirties. A cold front will bring a few showers and lower temperatures to Eastern Ontario on Friday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-29T03:04:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T11:05:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3480025253.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Unseasonably warm temperatures and high humidity expected today and Friday Time span: today and potentially into Friday. Maximum temperatures: Temperatures reaching or exceeding 30 degrees Celsius today. Temperatures Friday reaching 28 degrees C. Locations: Southern New Brunswick (cooler temperatures for coastal communities). Remarks: Temperatures are expected to reach or exceed 30 degrees today and 28 degrees on Friday. Humidex values are expected to reach 31 to 37. A cold front will bring a return to seasonable temperatures for the start of the weekend. Heat warnings have been issued for portions of northern and central New Brunswick. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-28T23:32:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T07:33:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3831650726.2020

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Freezing drizzle is occurring at Qikiqtarjuaq. Conditions are expected to improve this afternoon. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog is being observed along the north shore of Lake Superior and will remain in the area this morning. The fog may become more widespread this morning and may expand eastward towards Sault St. Marie. As a result, this advisory maybe expanded into these areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Surface temperatures are expected to fall below freezing tonight bringing patchy frost to portions of the central and southern Alberta. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke from a forest fire near Sabbies River may cause a reduction in air quality due to smoke in its vicinity and areas downwind to the east and northeast. Locations: Sabbies River to Rogersville and vicinity. Short range wind forecast: Winds light southwesterly becoming southwest 20 km/h this morning. Remarks: The forest fire was out of control on Wednesday morning and covering an estimated area of 838 hectares as reported by New Brunswick Natural resources and Energy Development. More information will be provided as it becomes available. ### Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-05-28T22:06:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the New Brunswick Department of Environment and Local Government, the New Brunswick Department of Health, 2020-05-28T07:36:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2961010975.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very warm and humid weather is expected. Time span: today and tonight, and continue Friday in some areas Locations: northwestern New Brunswick. Maximum temperature today: 32 degrees C (Humidex 37) Locations: Central and Northeastern New Brunswick. Maximum temperature today: 30 to 32 degrees C (Humidex 36 to 39) Minimum temperature tonight: 20 degrees C Maximum temperature Friday: 30 degrees C (Humidex 36 to 38) Remarks: Warm temperatures will reach or exceed 30 degrees over most of the province today. Temperatures Friday are expected to reach 30 degrees in parts of central and northeastern New Brunswick. Cooler conditions will occur this weekend. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-28T23:42:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-28T07:43:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1157162646.2020
